awd_titl_txt: Cybersecurity Fellows: The Scholarship for Service Program at Georgetown University
awd_abstract_narration:
This project seeks to establish a new CyberCorps®: Scholarship for Service (SFS) program at Georgetown University to prepare highly-qualified cybersecurity professionals for entry into the federal, state, local, or tribal government workforce. The proposal presents an innovative education program that takes a multifaceted approach to cybersecurity. The Cybersecurity Fellows Program at Georgetown will provide students with a broad view of cybersecurity. SFS students will not only learn the technical aspects of cybersecurity but will also understand domestic and foreign policy, politics, business, culture, and ethics. It is this broad view that the graduates of the proposed program will bring to Federal, State, Local, and Tribal Government organizations. The team has extensive experience in multiple areas within cybersecurity and has an established record of successfully engaging students in research, professional development, and in placing graduates in government organizations. More of Georgetown students have been choosing technical fields and the introductory computer science course enrollment has almost tripled in the last four years. The Cybersecurity Fellows program aims to diversify the cybersecurity workforce by recruiting, graduating, and placing women and members of underrepresented groups in government positions. The project will use Georgetown's relationship with the Cristo Rey network of high schools to recruit underrepresented students from urban schools to Georgetown. The Regents Scholars Program, a summer bridge program for underrepresented students in STEM, will help usher in well-prepared students for a rigorous science curriculum. The Cybersecurity Fellows program will offer additional faculty mentoring, interdisciplinary academic programming, and job placement services. 

Georgetown is designated as a DHS/NSA Center of Academic Excellence in Cyber Defense Research and its security programs are highly interdisciplinary with other areas including policy, law, international studies, and data science. The SFS students will be offered cybersecurity degrees in Computer Science; Science, Technology, and International Affairs; Security Studies; Public Policy; and Technology Management. Some examples of the interdisciplinary nature of the program include courses such as: Surveillance and Censorship; Information Warfare; Cyberspace and American Power; Cyber Conflict and Policy Dilemma; and Cybersecurity Conflict and Policy. Faculty members in the Computer Science department regularly collaborate and maintain strong ties with government organizations, including the U.S. Naval Research Laboratory, the Department of Homeland Security, the National Institute of Standards and Technology, the Naval Academy, and the National Institutes of Health. Students will have an opportunity to participate in applied and basic research on software security, system security and software technology problems in Georgetown's Security and Software Engineering Research Center.

por.por_cntn:
The Georgetown CyberCorps Program, funded under the NSF Scholarship for Service program, was designed to recruit and train students with both a technical and policy focus on cybersecurity. The program graduated 33 students across a variety of programs. At the undergraduate level students received degrees in Computer Science, Science and Technology in International Affairs, and Math, and at the graduate level in Security Studies, and Law. The program accomplished this by recruiting excellent students, with admission rates to the program being as low as 12% of applicants; through significant faculty and peer mentoring; and through strong institutional support including a good working relationship with the Cawley Career Center.

All graduates were employed in positions that met the program requirements at a variety of agencies, including: the Central Intelligence Agency; City of New York City; Cybersecurity And Infrastructure Security Agency; Defense Intelligence Agency; Federal Acquisition Services; Federal Bureau Of Investigation; Federal Reserve Bank Of Richmond; Federal Reserve Board of Governors; Government Accountability Office; MITRE; National Highway Traffic Safety Administration; National Institute Of Standards And Technology; National Security Agency; State Department; Public Safety And Homeland Security Bureau; the RAND Corporation; the U.S. Army; the U.S. Department Of Homeland Security; the U.S. Navy; and the U.S. Nuclear Regulatory Commission.

Students had a similarly varied placement for internships, working at: the Central Intelligence Agency; Cybersecurity And Infrastructure Security Agency; Defense Counterintelligence And Security Agency; Defense Intelligence Agency; Federal Bureau Of Investigation; Federal Reserve Board of Governors; Government Accountability Office; MITRE; the National Security Agency; the U.S. Army; the U.S. Department Of Homeland Security; the U.S. Marine Corps; the U.S. Navy; and the U.S. Nuclear Regulatory Commission.

Our students were a diverse group. Among the 33 students we graduated, 60% are women. Of the men, two self-reported as Hispanic, one as African American, and two others are military veterans. 

We additionally supported and recruited under-privileged students through Georgetown's Summer College Immersion Program. This program supports students from the Cristo Rey Network and Knowledge Is Power Program (KIPP) charter school systems. The Cristo Rey Network consists of 35 schools across the United States that prepare students from low-income families for post-secondary education. KIPP is a network of open enrollment, free charter schools in low-income areas that help prepare students for college. Of KIPP students, 95% are African American or Hispanic and more than 88% are eligible for federally subsidized meals. Under SCIP, students from these networks can apply to spend a month at Georgetown over the summer and attend classes and learn how to succeed in college. The PIs developed an Introduction to Cybersecurity course for SCIP and taught it over multiple summers. Many students from the program went on to college, and one of the students in the class enrolled in Computer Science at Georgetown. 


Last Modified: 01/22/2024
Modified by: Thomas C Shields
